description: One of Europe's largest public squares covering 7 hectares, Independence Square is the ceremonial heart of Minsk. Originally called Lenin Square when constructed in 1933, it features an impressive architectural ensemble blending pre-war constructivism with Soviet monumentalism and serves as the starting point of Independence Avenue.
highlights: One of the largest squares in Europe at 7 hectares
Designed by renowned Soviet architect Iosif Langbard in 1933
Government House - massive constructivist building housing Parliament
Red Church (Church of Saints Simon and Helena) with Neo-Romanesque architecture
Lenin statue as reminder of Soviet era
Site of major rallies including 2020 protests
tips: Easily accessible via Ploshcha Lyenina metro station
Visit the underground shopping center for local goods
Best photographed from multiple angles to capture the architectural ensemble
Evening visits showcase the musical fountain
Starting point for exploring Independence Avenue
vibe: Monumental, ceremonial, politically significant - the grand beating heart of modern Belarus where history and contemporary life converge
